Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Intelligent Systems for Health Condition Prognostics in AC Permanent Magnet and Induction Machine Drives for Highly Efficient and Renewable Energy Utilization and Generation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Most electric drives are currently employing induction machines in variable speed drives to reduce electric energy consumption. Latest hybrid vehicles, direct-drive wind turbine-generators and ultra-high efficiency heating and air-conditioning equipment employ brushless permanent magnet (BLPM) machine-drives for higher energy efficiency. Wider penetration of this technology requires an in-depth understanding of the fault mechanisms for developing fault prognostics and mitigation methods and robust fault tolerant designs.
Both ac BLPM synchronous and induction machines, referred to as ac machines, will be studied in this project. The objectives of this research are:
1. Develop novel fault diagnostic methods in ac machine-drives,
2. Discover novel nonlinear-estimation methods for prognosis of the useful life of ac machine-drives,
3. Discover techniques for fault mitigation in ac machine-drives to include a combination of adaptive control algorithms and novel fault-tolerant system topologies.
Broader Impact
The main benefits of this research are the development of fault prognostics and mitigation technologies for high efficiency ac machine-drives that the industrial partner, which is one of the largest electric machine manufacturers in North America, is well positioned to introduce into the market through a multitude of Original Equipment Manufacturers that it serves. The liaison between University and Industry will be enhanced by including reciprocal long term working visits and internships of faculty, students and engineers. The research results will be integrated into the graduate and undergraduate curricula. Under-represented groups will be targeted for participation. The results will be disseminated to the wider engineering community through professional journals and conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF-GOALI Project Outcome Report

    Adjustable speed machine-drives have been extensively used in various industrial automation applications over the past few decades due to their benefits of energy saving and control flexibilities. However, the wider penetration of motor-drive systems into industrial applications is hindered by the lack of health monitoring and fault-tolerant operation techniques, especially in some safety-critical applications, such as electric vehicles (EVs), all-electric aircrafts, medical instruments, and the like.  In this project, a complete portfolio of health condition monitoring techniques and fault-tolerant drive and machine topologies has been developed and implemented, which can significantly improve the fault-tolerant capabilities of such electric machine-drive systems.

    The first outcome of this project is the development of a lifetime improvement Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) method, namely, the novel discontinuous PWM (NDPWM) method, which can effectively extend the power cycling lifetime of Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistors (IGBTs) and other power electronic switches in power converters, especially for low-frequency operations. Under low-frequency conditions, the fundamental period of the inverter output is much larger than the thermal time constant of the IGBT modules. As a result, large oscillations in IGBT junction temperatures will occur, which will dramatically reduce the power cycling lifetime of IGBT modules. However, with this resulting PWM method, a zero-sequence signal is injected into the reference voltage signals to reduce the oscillations of IGBT junction temperatures, by which the remaining lifetime of the IGBT modules can be extended. Fig. 1 in the attachment depicts the improvement of the power converter lifetime of IGBT power inverters by using this novel method. Thermal modeling analysis, simulation results, as well as experimental results have been carried out to confirm the effectiveness of this novel PWM method. 

    The second outcome of this project is the development of a novel on-line diagnostic method for electronic switch faults in power converters. As is well-known that short-circuit and open-circuit switch faults are the most common faults that could occur in power converters. However, several solutions to mitigate short-circuit switch faults can be found in the literature, and can be considered to be technically mature. Nevertheless, very little attention has been paid to diagnosing open-circuit switch faults. Focusing on three-level neutral point clamped (NPC) inverters, a novel diagnostic method for open-circuit switch faults has been developed. This diagnostic method can diagnose any IGBT faults in a three-level NPC inverter by utilizing the information on the dc-bus neutral-point current, in conjunction with the instantaneous switching states. Such a novel diagnostic method only requires one additional current sensor for sensing the neutral-point current, and the diagnosis of an open-circuit switch fault can be completed within one fundamental power cycle. The functional flow chart of this novel diagnostic method is given in Fig. 2. Simulation and experimental results carried out by these investigators verified this proposed diagnostic method.

    The third outcome of this project is the development and implementation of a fault-tolerant topology for T-Type NPC power converters. The circuit topology of this fault-tolerant T-Type NPC converter is shown in Fig. 3. As can be seen, in this fault-tolerant topology, one more phase leg is added to the original T-Type NPC converter.
